Posts.Content: Hi all, find myself In a strange situation. 8 rounds of neoadjuvent chemo worked so well that there is no sign of the tumour in MRI or ultrasound scan. However, there was no marker put in at the original biopsy. The minor tissue conservation surgery cannot be completed as they cannot identify where the tumour was without the marker. Mastectomy is now the only way to safely proceed with surgery to a successful conclusion but is this really necessary given the results post chemotherapy as it seems so extreme now.

Posts.Content: Hi Worrier76, I'm the same as you regarding the  legal side, there is an investigation being undertaken which is most important to help make sure this doesn't happen again. The only thing that would make me go legal is if I find out that my reconstruction will need future surgery in a maintenance capacity? I don't know much about it yet but in 10/15/20 years would I have to have further surgery to maintain the appearance of the reconstruction. I'm 51 so plan on being around for quite some time! Thanks for taking time to reply.

Posts.Content: Thanks for support. They do have scan and mammogram images but have said they aren't accurate enough for tissue conservation surgery.
